title: ISO 9241 Guided Onboarding Sprint
theme: Design an onboarding journey aligned with ISO 9241-110 and ISO 9241-171
overview: This scenario follows a product team tasked with rebuilding the onboarding wizard of a SaaS collaboration suite. Students iterate from principle spotting to accessibility validation, always referencing ISO 9241 clauses as they make decisions.

labs.title: Lab A · Orientation Mapping
labs.summary: Diagnose onboarding friction and prioritize decisions using ISO 9241-110 principles.

labs.title: Lab B · Flow Crafting
labs.summary: Storyboard progressive disclosure moments and validate wording with ISO 9241-112 guidance.

labs.title: Lab C · Inclusive Validation
labs.summary: Stress-test the flow for accessibility and remote coaching, citing ISO 9241-171 and ISO 9241-210.

completionMessage: Capture lessons learned about inclusive onboarding and plan a usability benchmark for the next release.

challenges.title: Map Initial Friction
challenges.narrative: User success managers report that 60% of new teams abandon the wizard after step two. You must identify which ISO 9241-110 principles are violated and collect quick evidence.
objectives: Classify onboarding pain points against ISO 9241-110 dialogue principles.
Differentiate between cosmetic issues and genuine usability blockers.
Create a shared language for the rest of the sprint.

tasks.content: Review the onboarding step transcripts before watching any demo so you already know where testers hesitated.
tasks.helper: Skim timestamps for long pauses (00:45, 02:05, 03:40) and jot what distracted people.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-110 clause 5.3 (conformity with user expectations) and highlight wording you can reuse when naming blockers.
tasks.helper: Write one sentence in your own words explaining the clause so you can defend it later.

tasks.instruction: Populate the friction log template with at least five issues from steps 1–3, citing clause numbers and evidence.
tasks.example: Step 2 permissions — clause 5.3 — wizard forces advanced ACL setup before basics (timestamp 02:12).
checklist: Describe what the user tried to do
Quote the UI wording or behavior
Map to ISO clause + short rationale

tasks.instruction: Ask peers or the instructor which terms marketing uses in onboarding emails so the wizard stays consistent.
tasks.helper: Capture verbatim phrases (e.g., 'workspace roles', 'team coach') and compare them to what screenshots show.

tasks.instruction: Write three must-fix findings referencing clause 5.3 or 5.2, including evidence, risk, and desired outcome.
tasks.example: Finding: Welcome screen hides 'Skip tour' behind light text (00:32). Violates self-descriptiveness; novices assume the tour is mandatory. Ship: elevate button state.
checklist: Describe the risk in business/user language
Propose the improvement in one sentence

quizzes.question: A tooltip uses jargon unknown to first-time users. Which principle is broken?
quizzes.rationale: Jargon forces learners to guess meaning, hurting self-descriptiveness.

quizzes.question: The wizard forces users to configure advanced integrations before basic tasks. Which clause justifies rearranging steps?
quizzes.rationale: Tasks should mirror user goals; forcing advanced actions first violates suitability for the task.

challenges.nextStepCue: Once friction is mapped, prioritize improvements that will influence step sequencing.

challenges.title: Prioritize Guidance Elements
challenges.narrative: Marketing wants to highlight premium add-ons in the wizard, but you must defend user-centred decisions using ISO terminology.
objectives: Build a decision matrix balancing business asks and ISO 9241 compliance.
Select which prompts and UI helpers deserve engineering time.

tasks.content: List all proposed guidance elements: coach marks, inline video, checklist, upsell module.
tasks.helper: Write one sentence describing the business ask for each element so you can weigh trade-offs objectively.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-110 clause 5.6 on error tolerance and note when confirmation dialogs are justified.
tasks.helper: Underline any clause wording that mentions high-cost mistakes; you'll reuse it when defending your score.

tasks.instruction: Complete the guidance decision matrix, scoring impact and ISO risk for each helper.
checklist: Assign risk score tied to a clause

tasks.instruction: Scan two competitor onboarding flows and capture how they expose guidance without stealing control.
tasks.helper: Grab a screenshot or sketch plus one sentence describing why it works.

tasks.instruction: Recommend two guidance elements for engineering, quoting clause numbers and describing how you keep controllability intact.
tasks.example: Ship collapsible checklist (Clause 5.4) — gives users self-paced guardrails while letting them hide help when confident.
checklist: Call out mitigation for any residual risk

quizzes.question: Which helper best satisfies controllability?
choices: Offering a collapsible checklist the user can reopen
quizzes.rationale: A collapsible checklist keeps assistance available without taking control away.

quizzes.question: Where is error tolerance most impactful?
quizzes.rationale: Permission mistakes have high cost; confirmations here align with clause 5.6.

challenges.nextStepCue: With guidance decisions made, move into Lab B to storyboard the improved flow.

challenges.title: Storyboard Progressive Disclosure
challenges.narrative: You will storyboard a 7-step onboarding journey that gradually reveals advanced options while keeping novices confident.
objectives: Structure the wizard with progressive disclosure per ISO 9241-112.
Tie each step to a user goal and a clear feedback mechanism.

tasks.content: Open the storyboard template and label each column (intent, UI, copy, feedback) before sketching frames.
tasks.helper: Reserve frames 5–7 for advanced settings so you can show progressive disclosure explicitly.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-112 clause 9 for wording rules and paraphrase each clause in your own words.
tasks.helper: Write the paraphrased sentence at the top of your storyboard as a design guardrail.

tasks.instruction: Map each storyboard frame to an ISO principle (e.g., suitability for learning, self-descriptiveness) and document the trigger/feedback pair.
checklist: Add trigger arrow to next frame
Note ISO principle in last column
Mark frames that include feedback cues

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor how support teams monitor onboarding drop-offs so you can add telemetry triggers to your storyboard.
tasks.helper: Capture which step causes most escalations and bake an alert or helper into that frame.

tasks.instruction: Highlight two frames introducing advanced settings and explain the guardrails (copy, preview, confirmation) protecting novices.
tasks.example: Frame 6 opens automation rules under a disclosure arrow with inline preview + undo link, satisfying controllability.
checklist: Explain the guardrail and ISO clause
List metrics or signals you would monitor

quizzes.question: When introducing advanced options, which tactic best preserves suitability for learning?
choices: Hiding advanced options behind a clearly labelled disclosure
Mixing advanced and basic options randomly
quizzes.rationale: Progressive disclosure allows motivated users to expand details without overwhelming others.

quizzes.question: Which feedback channel fits ISO 9241-112 recommendations for immediate confirmation?
quizzes.rationale: Inline toasts near the action deliver timely context-sensitive feedback.

challenges.nextStepCue: Share the storyboard and move to Lab C to test inclusivity and remote coaching.

challenges.title: Accessibility Checklist Run
challenges.narrative: Accessibility champions need proof that the wizard supports keyboard-only navigation and assistive tech. You will run a fast ISO 9241-171 review.
objectives: Create a lightweight checklist referencing ISO 9241-171 sections 7.1–7.6.
Simulate a screen reader walkthrough to capture gaps.
Recommend remediation tasks for engineering and content teams.

tasks.content: Review the prototype notes to understand how focus order, tooltips, and banners currently behave before testing.
tasks.helper: Write down any DOM order surprises so you can reproduce them for engineers.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-171 sections 7.2–7.6 to recall requirements for focus indication, redundant cues, and error descriptions.
tasks.helper: Underline wording about redundant cues; you will cite it verbatim in your findings.

tasks.instruction: Run through the checklist, logging pass/fail plus evidence (GIF, screenshot, quote) for each checkpoint.
Ask the instructor whether corporate branding can adapt to meet contrast requirements and note constraints (brand colors, legal limits).
tasks.helper: If branding is fixed, document alternative mitigations (outline thickness, patterns).

tasks.instruction: Summarize the top three accessibility risks, each pairing evidence, ISO clause, and remediation owner.
tasks.example: Risk: Success banner uses color only (Clause 7.4). Evidence: screenshot + hex values. Fix: add icon + aria-live alert (Content owner).

quizzes.question: Which issue violates ISO 9241-171 guidance on focus indication?
quizzes.rationale: Keyboard traps prevent focus from moving predictably, breaching accessibility guidance.

quizzes.question: What redundant cue helps color-blind users understand success states?
quizzes.rationale: Text or icon reinforcement keeps feedback perceivable beyond color alone.

challenges.nextStepCue: With accessibility risks logged, move to the final challenge to define remote coaching support.

challenges.title: Remote Coaching Brief
challenges.narrative: Support teams will coach customers remotely. Design a validation plan that verifies guidance works over screen-share sessions using ISO 9241-210 and ISO 9241-11 metrics.
objectives: Specify context-of-use assumptions for remote calls.
Choose metrics for effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction.
Draft mitigation strategies for coaching-specific risks.

tasks.content: Plan for 30-minute remote coaching sessions covering two personas (ops lead, project manager) using screen-share and shared notes.
tasks.helper: Note time zones and preferred collaboration tools so you can schedule realistically.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-11 clause 5 to capture the exact definitions of effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction before picking metrics.
tasks.helper: Translate each dimension into a question you can actually ask during the call.

tasks.instruction: Outline the study flow (pre-brief, live walkthrough, post-session survey) and assign owners, prompts, and measurement points.
checklist: Add talk track for each stage
Define when the coach steps back

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor (legal proxy) about data privacy constraints for recordings, consent, and storage.
tasks.helper: Record answers verbatim so you can paste them into the risk section.

tasks.instruction: Complete the remote coaching brief with participants, context assumptions, ISO-aligned metrics, success criteria, and follow-up actions.
tasks.example: Effectiveness metric: % of steps completed without prompts (target ≥ 80%). Efficiency: time to configure workspace (target ≤ 6 min).

quizzes.question: Which metric captures effectiveness for remote coaching?
choices: Percentage of tasks completed without coach intervention
quizzes.rationale: Effectiveness measures task completion quality, so autonomy during coaching is key.

quizzes.question: Which risk mitigation aligns with ISO 9241-210's evaluation activity?
choices: Documenting findings and iterating the prototype
Allowing coaches to improvise without notes
quizzes.rationale: Capturing findings and iterating ensures evaluation informs design solutions.

challenges.nextStepCue: Reveal the class score and collect feedback on the remote coaching plan.
